title: "Market Structure & Competition"
subtitle: "Monopoly, Cooperation, and Fair Competition"
abstract: |
  This chapter analyzes different market structures through an Islamic lens, examining monopoly in Islamic law, cooperative business models, and the ethical principles of fair competition. We contrast Islamic approaches to market concentration with conventional economic analysis and explore mudarabah and musharakah-based firm structures as alternatives to purely capitalist enterprises.

# Introduction {.unnumbered}

*This chapter is under development. Check back soon for the full content.*

## What This Chapter Will Cover

- Perfect competition as an Islamic ideal versus monopoly
- Islamic law's position on monopoly (ihtikar) and market concentration
- Cartels and price-fixing in Islamic jurisprudence
- Mudarabah and musharakah models and market structure
- Cooperative enterprises and their role in Islamic economies
- Fair competition and the prohibition of unfair trade practices
- Market power and ethical constraints on market dominance
- Comparison with conventional industrial organization theory

::: {.callout-tip title="Key Concept"}
Islamic economics favors competitive market structures while emphasizing the ethical constraints that must govern firm behavior, prohibiting monopolistic practices (ihtikar) and promoting cooperative arrangements that distribute wealth and opportunity more equitably.
:::
